question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective method for controlling invasive bracken in shrublands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents on bracken control in shrublands reports: Cutting bracken showed mixed outcomes, with some studies finding increased heather cover or biomass and reduced bracken cover/biomass, while others found no increase in heather cover or seedling abundance and mixed or no reduction in bracken; cutting also increased species richness in one study, did not alter richness but increased diversity in another, increased cover of wavy hair-grass and sheep’s fescue, and did not increase gorse or common cow-wheat abundance (1653). Combining cutting with herbicide did not alter heather biomass in one UK study, increased heather cover in a Norway study, had no significant effect on cover of seven plant species in one UK study, increased plant species richness when cutting preceded herbicide compared to the reverse order, and reduced bracken biomass or cover in multiple studies (1654). Using herbicide with leaf-litter removal did not increase total plant biomass after eight years, but in three of six years heather biomass was higher than with herbicide alone (1660). No studies were found evaluating effects of cutting and burning bracken (1655) or using herbicide with sowing of shrubland seeds to control bracken (1658). A systematic review reported that repeated applications of the herbicide asulam reduced bracken abundance and that cutting may be equally effective; a laboratory trial found asulam inhibited growth of three common moss species after three weeks’ exposure but not after 24 hours (105).
summary_statements: Cutting bracken in shrublands showed mixed outcomes.
Some studies found that cutting bracken led to increased heather cover or biomass and reduced bracken cover or biomass.
Other studies found no increase in heather cover or seedling abundance after cutting bracken.
Other studies found mixed or no reduction in bracken after cutting.
One study found that cutting bracken increased species richness.
Another study found that cutting bracken did not alter species richness but did increase species diversity.
Cutting bracken increased the cover of wavy hair-grass and sheep’s fescue.
Cutting bracken did not increase gorse or common cow-wheat abundance.
In one UK study, combining cutting with herbicide did not alter heather biomass.
In a Norway study, combining cutting with herbicide increased heather cover.
Combining cutting with herbicide had no significant effect on the cover of seven plant species in one UK study.
Plant species richness increased when cutting preceded herbicide application compared to the reverse order.
Combining cutting with herbicide reduced bracken biomass or cover in multiple studies.
Using herbicide with leaf-litter removal did not increase total plant biomass after eight years.
In three of six years, heather biomass was higher when using herbicide with leaf-litter removal than with herbicide alone.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of cutting and burning bracken.
No studies were found evaluating the use of herbicide with the sowing of shrubland seeds to control bracken.
A systematic review reported that repeated applications of the herbicide asulam reduced bracken abundance.
A systematic review reported that cutting may be equally effective as repeated applications of the herbicide asulam for reducing bracken.
A laboratory trial found the herbicide asulam inhibited the growth of three common moss species after three weeks of exposure.
A laboratory trial found the herbicide asulam did not inhibit the growth of three common moss species after 24 hours of exposure.

question_details.query: What is the success rate of legally protecting specific plant species from gathering in shrublands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: There is no available evidence on the success of legally protecting plant species affected by gathering in shrublands; no studies evaluating this action were found [1612]. Relatedly, no studies were found evaluating the effects of legally protecting shrubland habitat or habitat around shrubland on shrublands [1674; 1675].
summary_statements: There is no available evidence on the success of legally protecting plant species affected by gathering in shrublands.
No studies evaluating the action of legally protecting plant species affected by gathering in shrublands were found.
No studies were found evaluating the effects on shrublands of legally protecting shrubland habitat.
No studies were found evaluating the effects on shrublands of legally protecting habitat around shrubland.
